title: Schedule Compression Techniques
description: Master fast tracking and crashing techniques to compress project schedules while managing cost, risk, and quality trade-offs.
objectives: Distinguish between fast tracking (performing activities in parallel) and crashing (adding resources to reduce duration)
Select the appropriate compression technique based on budget status, resource availability, and dependency constraints
Identify critical path activities that must be compressed to reduce total project duration
Recognize the trade-offs: Fast tracking increases risk while crashing increases cost
Avoid compressing quality/testing activities inappropriately when safety or compliance cannot be compromised

screens.headline: Grand opening moved up 3 weeks. Budget: $60K remaining. Question: Can you finish on time without blowing the budget?

visual.left: Original 12-week Gantt chart with sequential activities
visual.right: Compressed 9-week timeline with red 'DEADLINE MOVED' stamp
visual.characters: Carlos looks stressed, Sam holds budget spreadsheet marked 'RISK: OVERRUN'

dialogue.text: Alex, I don't care if we go over budget. This celebrity chef opening is make-or-break for Savory & Co. Do whatever it takes.

screens.learningHook: Your job: Compress 3 weeks from the schedule. But crashing (adding resources) costs money. Fast tracking (parallel work) adds risk. Choose wisely—one wrong decision could blow the budget OR fail the health inspection.

screens.title: Compression Technique Selection
screens.instructions: For each critical path activity, select the appropriate compression technique (fast track, crash, or other options). A running budget tracker shows the cost impact of your decisions.

currentStatus.criticalPathActivities: Electrical & Plumbing (4 weeks), Equipment Installation (3 weeks), Staff Training (2 weeks)

scenarios.title: Electrical & Plumbing Work
scenarios.currentDuration: 4 weeks (2 weeks electrical, 2 weeks plumbing - sequential)
scenarios.situation: ElectraPlumb Co. does both electrical and plumbing work but has only one crew, so work is currently scheduled sequentially. This activity is on the critical path and consumes 4 of the 12 weeks. You need to save at least 1 week here.
constraints: Electrical and plumbing CAN be done in parallel if you hire separate crews
Current contractor does both, but sequentially (only one crew available)
Hiring a second specialized contractor would cost +$15K but could run plumbing parallel to electrical, saving 2 weeks total

questions.question: Which compression technique should Alex use?

options.text: Fast track: Run electrical and plumbing in parallel by hiring a second contractor
Crash: Add more workers to the existing contractor's crew to finish both faster
Do nothing - this activity cannot be compressed without violating building codes
Crash: Pay the current contractor overtime to work weekends and finish in 2 weeks

feedback.correct: Perfect! Fast tracking is the ideal choice here. You're parallelizing sequential work by hiring separate crews, saving 2 weeks at $15K cost.
feedback.incorrect: Review: This is a perfect fast tracking scenario—parallel crews can work simultaneously in different zones.

scenarios.title: Kitchen Equipment Installation
scenarios.situation: Installing industrial ovens, refrigeration units, ventilation systems, and prep stations. Currently planned with a 2-person crew over 3 weeks. This is on the critical path and CANNOT START until electrical & plumbing are complete (hard dependency). You need to save at least 1 week here.
constraints: HARD DEPENDENCY: Equipment installation CANNOT start until electrical/plumbing are complete
Fast tracking not possible with preceding activities
Currently under budget; could afford to add installation crew members
Rashid confirms: Equipment vendor can provide a 4-person crew instead of 2-person for +$12K, reducing duration to 1.5 weeks

questions.question: Which compression technique should Alex use?

options.text: Fast track: Start equipment installation before electrical/plumbing are fully complete
Crash: Add more installation crew members to reduce duration from 3 weeks to 1.5 weeks
Do nothing - 3 weeks is the minimum safe installation time
Fast track: Overlap equipment installation with staff training to save time

feedback.correct: Correct! This is crashing (adding resources). Cost: +$12K (affordable). Respects the dependency. Saves 1.5 weeks on critical path.
feedback.incorrect: Review: Hard dependencies prevent fast tracking. Equipment REQUIRES completed electrical/plumbing.

scenarios.title: Staff Training Program
scenarios.situation: Training kitchen staff on new equipment, safety protocols, and menu preparation. Currently planned as 2 weeks of hands-on training AFTER equipment is installed. This is the final activity before health inspection. You need to save at least 0.5 weeks here.
constraints: Training CANNOT start until equipment installation is complete
HOWEVER: CLASSROOM training (safety, menu theory, health code review) CAN happen in parallel with equipment installation
Hands-on training (1 week) still requires completed installation
Sam warns: We're at $60K remaining budget. Already spending $15K (electrical) + $12K (equipment) = $27K spent. We have $33K left.

questions.question: Which compression technique should Alex use?

options.text: Fast track: Run classroom training in parallel with equipment installation, then do hands-on training after
Crash: Hire additional trainers to reduce training duration from 2 weeks to 1 week
Reduce training to 1 week by cutting content to meet the deadline
Do nothing - 2 weeks of training is non-negotiable for safety compliance

feedback.correct: Correct! This is fast tracking. Classroom training doesn't depend on installed equipment. Saves ~0.5 weeks. Zero additional cost.
feedback.incorrect: Review: Classroom training CAN be parallelized with equipment installation, saving time without cost.

blocks.title: Two Ways to Compress a Schedule

comparison.fastTracking: Performing activities IN PARALLEL that were originally planned in SEQUENCE
comparison.crashing: Adding RESOURCES to critical path activities to reduce their duration

comparison.fastTracking: No cost increase (or minimal if hiring separate crews)
comparison.crashing: Cost INCREASES (overtime, additional staff, expedited delivery)

comparison.fastTracking: Risk INCREASES (coordination issues, potential rework if dependencies violated)
comparison.crashing: Risk may increase slightly (quality issues if rushed)

comparison.fastTracking: Activities CAN be done in parallel (no hard dependencies), Budget is tight
comparison.crashing: Hard dependencies prevent fast tracking, Budget available, Resources can be added effectively

content.keyInsight: Fast tracking is cheaper but riskier. Crashing is more expensive but respects dependencies. PMI best practice: Try fast tracking FIRST.

blocks.title: Critical Path Focus - You MUST Compress Critical Path Activities

content.keyInsight: Compressing non-critical activities does NOT reduce total project duration. You MUST focus on the critical path.

example.wrong: Compressing a non-critical activity (e.g., faster furniture delivery) saves NO time on the overall project.
example.right: Compressing Electrical from 4 weeks to 2 weeks DOES reduce total project duration because Electrical is ON the critical path.

decisionTree.question: Is the activity on the critical path?
decisionTree.no: Don't compress it—won't reduce total project duration

decisionTree.question: Are there hard dependencies preventing parallel work?
decisionTree.yes: Fast tracking not feasible. Consider crashing.
decisionTree.no: Fast tracking is possible. Proceed to next question.

decisionTree.question: Is budget available for additional resources?
decisionTree.yes: Choose between fast tracking (lower cost, higher coordination risk) and crashing (higher cost, lower risk). PMI best practice: Try fast tracking FIRST.

decisionTree.question: Does the activity involve quality/testing that cannot be rushed?
decisionTree.yes: Do NOT compress by cutting content. Consider crashing with more resources OR fast track other activities.
decisionTree.no: Proceed with fast tracking or crashing based on previous questions.

wp1_correct.text: Smart move. We're running electrical and plumbing simultaneously with separate crews. Saves 2 weeks, costs $15K. That's efficient compression.

wp2_correct.text: Perfect. Vendor confirmed the 4-person crew can safely finish in 1.5 weeks. We're spending $12K to save 1.5 weeks on the critical path. That's smart crashing.

wp3_correct.text: Brilliant. We're teaching theory and safety during installation week, then doing hands-on training once equipment is ready. No cost, saves half a week.

overall_excellent.text: Alex, you just saved us from disaster. I wanted to throw $40K+ at overtime crashing. You fast tracked where possible, crashed only where necessary. We're ahead of schedule, under budget, and no safety shortcuts.

screens.title: New Urgent Scenario - Savory & Co. Expansion Project Behind Schedule
screens.context: Two months later, Savory & Co. is opening a SECOND location. The project is 2 weeks behind schedule, and the lease start date is fixed. Alex must compress the schedule by 2 weeks to avoid paying rent on an empty space.

currentStatus.contingency: Stakeholders approved an additional $15K if absolutely necessary
currentStatus.scheduleStatus: 2 weeks behind (must compress 2 weeks to meet lease start date)

criticalPathActivities.name: Interior Painting
criticalPathActivities.crashOption: Can be done faster with more painters. Vendor quote: +$6K for extra crew = 1 week duration

criticalPathActivities.name: Furniture Delivery & Setup
criticalPathActivities.crashOption: Vendor says lead time is FIXED (manufacturer constraint, cannot be expedited)

criticalPathActivities.name: IT/POS System Installation
criticalPathActivities.crashOption: Currently sequential: Network setup (0.5 weeks), then POS installation (1 week). These CAN be done by separate vendors in parallel. Cost: +$4K for separate POS installer = 0.5 weeks total duration (saves 1 week)

questions.question: Which compression strategy gets you back on schedule (save 2 weeks) at the LOWEST cost?

options.text: Crash painting (save 1 week, cost $6K) + Fast track IT/POS (save 1 week, cost $4K) = Total savings: 2 weeks, cost $10K
Crash painting (save 1 week, cost $6K) + Negotiate with furniture vendor to expedite delivery (assume 1 week saved, cost unknown/risky)
Fast track IT/POS only (save 1 week, cost $4K) and negotiate a 1-week delay with stakeholders
Crash both painting and IT/POS installation (assume 2 weeks total saved, cost $10K+)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Option A is the optimal strategy: crash painting + fast track IT/POS. Total compression: 2 weeks. Total cost: $10K (within $15K contingency).
feedback.incorrect: Review: Furniture delivery is a fixed constraint. Fast tracking IT/POS is cheaper than crashing it. Achieve exactly 2 weeks at lowest cost.

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned to compress project schedules using two techniques: fast tracking and crashing. The key is choosing the right technique based on dependencies, budget, and risk tolerance.
takeaways: Fast tracking = Parallelizing originally sequential activities (low/no cost, increases risk from coordination complexity)
Crashing = Adding resources to critical path activities (increases cost, requires budget and resource availability)
You MUST compress critical path activities to reduce total project duration
PMI best practice: Try fast tracking FIRST (least costly option), then crash if fast tracking isn't feasible or sufficient
Respect hard dependencies—violating them causes rework, safety issues, and inspection failures
NEVER compromise quality/safety to meet schedule (don't cut testing time or safety training)
